active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between parameterized queries, stored procedures, and Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) for SQLi prevention. Use real-world examples like the 2011 Sony Pictures breach to argue which is most effective in a secure SDLC and why.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Bloom's Taxonomy, active learning, and secure coding practices. Generate 80 high-quality flashcards on 'Parameterized Queries (SQL Injection Prevention)' in the topic hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Software Development Security > Software Development Ecosystems > 006_Secure Implementation and Coding > Secure Coding Practices > Parameterized Queries (SQL Injection Prevention). Incorporate: - Voter consensus: Code examples in Python (psycopg2), Java (PreparedStatement), PHP (PDO); contrast vulnerable dynamic queries; best practices (prioritize params, safe stored procs, input validation, avoid escaping); real breaches (Sony 2011); OWASP Top 10, SDLC, compliance (GDPR/PCI-DSS). - Research: SQLi via string concat; params as data (not code); sources (OWASP Cheat Sheet, NIST). - Learning objectives: [INSERT FULL LIST FROM ABOVE]. - Active learning: Weave in discussion/peer/problem-solving elements. - Scaffolding: Distribute across 4 layers [INSERT FULL LAYERS FROM ABOVE]. Use EXACT flashcard schema: Multiple-choice (1 correct, 3 distractors per protocol), front/back format. Output as JSON array of objects: [{'front': {'question': '...', 'options': [...], 'correct': 'A'}, 'back': {'answer': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'code_example': '...', 'reference': '...'}}, ...]. Ensure spaced repetition friendly: Varied formats, progressive difficulty, explanations reference Bloom's levels and layers.
